abstract.t:
Tagbibs (or simply: 'bibs') are tiny tags, allowing mere mortals to connect words to other words using pencil, voice or keyboard.
They expand into multiple BibTags.
For example, using OCR, scanned paper can 'connect' with online graphs.
Think of it as the brother of hashtags: a command for tagging-this-with-that.
The goal of this spec is three-fold:

ul.li: specify bibs: a terse tagdescription which expands into a reversed BibTag
specify bibs as URI fragment: a way to hint browsers to jump to (bib)tagged content
specify bibrulers: dumb line-based separators for bibtags

section.name: What are bibs
section.t: bibs allow non-technical humans to write reversed BibTags in a short-form (on paper):

blockquote.t: Basically means: add laundry to tag @chores and tag @todo, by expanding into the following BibTags:

the word laundry can now be highlighted in the human text. bibs are basically one step up from socialmedia hashtags, allowing mere mortals to connect words to other words using pencil, voice or keyboard.

section.t: There's no precise predicates or properties (just 'this points to that', which empowers citizen annotation (an essential precursor of RDF).

blockquote.t: syntactically, bibs are (concatenated) emaildomains without an extension

ol.li: at least 2 @ characters need to occur, to qualify as a bib
last bib wins: overlapping bibs overwrite eachother (last tag(s) win)
spaces are not allowed, maximum by using + to represents spaces (the+bill@todo e.g.)

Merging (BibTagged) overlaps
section.t: When a bib (great+gatsby@book is copy-pasted into another document (a PDF or Textfile with a visual-meta appendix e.g.):

ol.li: the editor should check for the existence of @book{great+gatsby
if exist: do nothing, leave target document as is
if not: create the expanded BibTag
optionally, the editor can offer to add properties (as bibs are propertyless)

blockquote.t: propertyless bibs, are a great way as a 'process later'-medium ("I wrote down great+gatsby@readinglist on a papertowel/email, to scan/copy-paste it later)
